I am a senior data analyst with experience developing analytic tools and supporting policy research.
I am hooked on the idea that data analytics and behavioural science can improve the everyday decision-making of individuals and institutions.
While at the RAND Corporation, I developed decision-making analytics tools, streamlined data collection methods, and analyzed survey data for research projects on Truth Decay, criminal justice, and education. 
Contributing to the world around me, even through the diffuse mechanisms of research, is what drives my work.

After my time at RAND, I had planned to pursue a Masters in economics in Europe, but as the school year approached I began to feel this was not the right path for me.
Living in the Los Angeles rental market, I needed to find a job fairly quickly to keep afloat.
I knew I was good at data analysis and enjoyed programming so I decided to look for a role in data analytics.
I wanted to combine my analytics skills with my background in behavioural science to make data accessible to decision-makers and improve organizations' decision-making processes.
Over the past 3 years I have led projects evaluating data quality, strengthened the decision-making capacity of senior leadership by building powerful interactive dashboards, and enhanced collaboration between analytics and other departments by coordinating analytics working groups.

While I enjoy working in analytics, I haven't found the same fulfilment as I did working on policy research.
I want to build a high-impact career that addresses the pressing problems in our world, which I think is best achieved through improving the structures and processes of important institutions' decision-making.
I struggled to put this into words until I stumbled across [80,000 Hours](https://80000hours.org/).
Reading through their [key ideas](https://80000hours.org/key-ideas/) and listening to hours of the [80,000 Hours podcast](https://80000hours.org/podcast/) cemented my goal of using my career to make a difference.
